unnormalised: ## The Great Indian Return Saga: A Comedy of Errors (and Sarees)
normalised: ## The Great Indian Return Saga: A Comedy of Errors (and Sarees)

unnormalised: Let's face it, navigating return policies in India can feel like trying to find a parking spot in Chandni Chowk on Diwali – a complete and utter madhouse. You think you’ve scored a great deal on that "silk" saree from "Saree Emporium" online, only to find it feels suspiciously like plastic. And then the return process begins… oh, the horror!
normalised: Let's face it, navigating return policies in India can feel like trying to find a parking spot in Chandni Chowk on Diwali – a complete and utter madhouse. You think you’ve scored a great deal on that "silk" saree from "Saree Emporium" online, only to find it feels suspiciously like plastic. And then the return process begins… oh, the horror!

unnormalised: Retailers, bless their cotton socks, have return policies that can rival the complexity of the Indian Constitution. You'll need a PhD in fine print deciphering just to figure out if you're eligible. Was it purchased before 10:00 hrs on 26/01/2023? Does it have all original tags, even the tiny one you accidentally used as a bookmark? Did you try to bargain with the delivery guy like you would at your local sabzi mandi? (That last one might not affect the return, but hey, it's India!)

You'll need a P H D in fine print deciphering just to figure out if you're eligible. Was it purchased before ten hours on twenty sixth January two thousand and twenty three? Does it have all original tags, even the tiny one you accidentally used as a bookmark? Did you try to bargain with the delivery guy like you would at your local sabzi mandi? (That last one might not affect the return, but hey, it's India!)

unnormalised: And don't even get me started on the justifications. "But madam, you wore it to your cousin's wedding and danced the Nagin dance! Clearly, it's no longer in 'original condition!'" Or the classic: "Sir, our policy states returns are only accepted between 2 PM and 4 PM on Tuesdays, except on public holidays that fall on a Tuesday. Today is Wednesday, and while it's close to Tuesday... tough luck!"

unnormalised: Remember that time I tried returning a pressure cooker from "Sharma Ji Appliances"? It was dented! They claimed it was "vintage styling." Vintage! It looked like it had survived the Partition (15/08/1947, just saying!). After a week of emails and phone calls more frustrating than dealing with Auntie Saroj's matchmaking skills, they finally accepted the return. I almost cried tears of joy, which I then meticulously documented in case *those* needed returning too.

unnormalised: So, next time you're eyeing that tempting online deal, remember the Great Indian Return Saga. Read the fine print. Pray to Lord Ganesha. And maybe, just maybe, you'll emerge victorious… or at least with a slightly less dented bank balance. Good luck, my friends. You'll need it. And maybe a lawyer. And definitely chai.
